He consi- book dered the importance of the war, and made an estimate of his strength, the resources in his power, and the forces at a distance, as well as those that lay near at hand. The legions were devoted to his interest, inso- much that, when he showed himself the first to swear fidelity to Vitellius, and offer up vows for the prosperity of his reign, the soldiers marked their displeasure by a sul- len silence. Mucianus was the friend of Titus, and by no means averse from the father. The praefect of iEgypt, whose name was Alexander, was ready to pro- mote the enterprise. The third legion, which had been removed from Syria to Maesia, Vespasian considered as his own, and had, besides, good reason to hope, that the forces in lllyricum would enter into the confederacy.
